title.narrative: Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty

description.narrative: In Q4 2021, our Tanzania program concluded the enrollment of 57,089 farmers for the 2022 season. This is below initial projections, as the effects of the global pandemic continued to inhibit our scale-up last year. Tanzania is designated as one of our ‘growth countries’, which refers to contexts where we are actively adjusting and refining our program and approach to optimize impact, growth, and sustainability.

Our prior project with the Dutch Government, “Subsistence to Self-Reliance – Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers” underscored our shared passion for inclusive economic development and showcased the key milestones that we can accomplish together. Core operating support from DGIS facilitated the strategic expansion of One Acre Fund’s ‘impact ecosystem.’ Within two years, we doubled the scale of our farmer network, launched operations in two new country programs (Malawi and Uganda), and rolled out impactful new products like tree planting kits and clean cookstoves at country-wide scale. Simultaneously, we refined our innovative systems-change platform, leveraging our core organizational competencies to improve large-scale public and private actors’ service to smallholders. This success has now placed One Acre Fund in a position where we can realistically envision moving the needle on hunger and poverty across the entire African continent. Our current project with DGIS, “Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty,” aims to capture this powerful opportunity. The project involves a smartly structured two-part investment spanning September 15, 2018 – December 31, 2022: First, DGIS is once again providing critical support to the varied, evolving platforms within our organization that lay the foundation for our growth and impact. Core operating support from DGIS will enhance and extend One Acre Fund’s proven model by funding key strategic priorities across our M&E, R&D, and new country expansion units. Secondly, DGIS is also providing working capital to revolutionize One Acre Fund’s growth trajectory. This injection to our ‘permanent fund’ will completely fund our projected expansion of 245,000+ new farm families in 2019, bringing us past the 1 millionth farmer milestone. Crucially, farmers’ loan repayments will replenish our permanent fund each year, allowing us to re-extend this contribution to provide input loans to an estimated 245,000 farm families (including over 980,000 children) annually. This project will anchor One Acre Fund’s expansion to directly serve 1.85 million farm families annually by year-end 2022. Simultaneously, it will help us reach an additional 3.5 million farmers via systems-change partnerships that are expressly designed to transform entire agricultural ecosystems. Together, the reach of these efforts will generate transformative change for rural communities across rural Africa.

title.narrative: One Acre Fund's key cost-effectiveness measure.

comment.narrative: Despite strong deficit-cutting, SROI was below target, primarily due to the aforementioned impact shortfall. We would also like to note that in the early years, Kenya and Rwanda also had SROIs below 1 (it takes time to build client trust and realize higher transactions and economies of scale to improve SROI).

We collected 94.7% of total loans disbursed country-wide in 2020, below our historical average of 97%. However, this is an improvement from our 2019 season’s result of 92% — a particularly positive outcome given the challenges faced by farmers during the pandemic. The main factors driving the year-over-year decrease in SROI include: lower revenues due to narrow margins, higher costs due to unbudgeted COVID-19 spending (including health trainings to clients and soap distribution to clients and their neighbors), and higher transport costs related to fertilizer supply chain challenges.

We measure our efficiency, or Social Return On Investment (SROI), as the amount of new profits our farmers generate for every $1 of donor investment in our program. We project SROI from our Tanzania program to fall slightly below target in 2021. Along with slightly lower impact, costs were higher than projected, particularly due to increased global fertilizer prices. On the revenue side, loan repayment exceeded our targets at 97.5% (vs a target of 94%).

title.narrative: Farm families reached through systems-change unit

comment.narrative: Given the strong relations we have with the government and the credibility of our growing core program, Tanzania has shown early potential for impact through our systems-change work. In 2019, we worked to strengthen partnerships in our ongoing rural retail shops project (as outlined in our previous updates) and advocacy on the removal of VAT (value-added tax) for impactful PICS crop storage bags.

In 2020, our systems change work in Tanzania consisted of two workflows: 1) a marketing incentive trial that uses a voucher subsidy to improve the adoption of hybrid maize seed and fertilizer in low adoption areas; and 2) the distribution of tree seedlings. We reached 28,000 farmers through the seed voucher program, and 4,000 through our agroforestry platform.

We define farm families 'reached' as households that benefitted from at least one systems-change intervention. We served 44,000 families through our systems-change platform (i.e., beyond our core program clients) in Tanzania in 2021. Agroforestry is the most important tenet of our systems-change work in Tanzania, and we have therefore shifted our focus this year to deepen the impact of our tree-planting program rather than simply increasing distributions. To improve environmental and economic outcomes for those participating in our tree planting program, we are launching a timber trial whereby farmers would commit to dedicating a full acre of land to timber production (~300 seedlings), with the intention of harvesting and replanting at regular intervals. We recently completed enrollment for this trial and exceeded our 300 farmer scale target.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: The profit boost achieved by farming with One Acre Fund.

comment.narrative: Impact challenges in our growth countries (Uganda, Malawi, Tanzania, and Zambia) caused social return on investment (SROI) to dip below our targets for this cohort in 2019. Uncontrollable, external factors such as severe weather shocks, market price movements, currency fluctuations, and other shocks severely influenced our impact and SROI which led to lower harvests and farmer revenue, respectively. These factors decreased impact and farmer repayment while negatively affecting our revenue model via lower farmer repayment—i.e. decreasing our SROI. Our impact forecasts in Tanzania have meaningfully evolved since launching our latest partnership there in 2017. One Acre Fund Tanzania program is part of our ‘growth countries unit,’ a designation that refers to contexts where we are still refining our programming to achieve reliable impact and growth. Performance in such countries tends to be variable in line with changing realities on the ground; in Tanzania, two consecutive seasons (2018 and 2019) of challenging weather and low maize prices increased farmer risk aversion, affecting impact. Final impact figures will be shared in our 2020 Q1 update.

Our clients will achieve an average $50.9 incremental profit per farmer on supported activities, below our three-year average of $112. Despite impact levers such as the promotion of crop diversification, increased planting compliance, and stronger support for volunteer Group Leaders, flooding in the Southern Districts appear to have negatively affected our impact results.

While analysis is ongoing, we tentatively expect to fall short of our 2021 impact target. A positive driver has included our agroforestry program (detailed above) and initiatives to increase our product offerings, providing diverse income avenues. This year, we launched early-stage trials of new crops (e.g., biofortified beans) with the potential to further diversify farm families’ incomes and nutrition, and expanded our tree portfolio to include avocado, pine, grevillea, and two soil-improving varieties, in addition to the launch of our timber trial detailed above.

title.narrative: Farm families participating in One Acre Fund's core program.

comment.narrative: We concluded Tanzania's 2019 season serving 56,000 farm families country-wide slightly below our grant target of 60,000. We attribute this to two consecutive seasons (2018 and 2019) of challenging weather and low maize prices that have increased farmer risk aversion, affecting enrollment.

We finalized the 2020 season in Q3 of 2020, having served 61,400 farmers country-wide. This falls below our internal target for the year, and results from the program’s decision to deliberately slow growth and focus on program fundamentals following two seasons of impact and repayment challenges.

We served a below-target 55,000 clients in the 2021 farm season. While we continue to see strong demand for our model, we are delaying a return to more aggressive growth as we focus on improving impact/SROI in the country. We therefore anticipate conservative growth in 2022, as noted above.
